meanings.definition: A long work of fiction, usually having a plot and characters.
examples: If I read one chapter each night, I will finish the novel in two weeks.

images.alt: Photo of books on a table.
images.description: Many chapter books are gathered on a table. Books titles include Eragon, Where rainbows end, Prep, P.S. Love You, If You Could See Me Now, and five books from the Chronicles of Narnia series.
images.caption: Dive in and get lost in a great novel!

meanings.definition: To cause, urge, stimulate or influence to do.
examples: My mother's kindness inspired me to write a book about her.

meanings.definition: A group of people gathered to see or hear something.
examples: The audience was silent during his speech.

images.alt: Photo of a crowd of people around a stage.
images.description: A large number are shown, gathered around a stage.
images.caption: This audience looks ready to hear a debate!

meanings.definition: A subject being talked about.
examples: Andre believed that a lot of issues could be settled by people talking and listening to each other.

images.alt: Photo of trash on a beach.
images.description: A sandy beach with plastic bottles, straws, bottle caps, buckets, styrofoam, and other trash and rocks and sticks on it. Boats float on water in the background.
images.caption: Pollution is a key issue that needs to be solved.

source.title: Garbage on Pantai Pangalisang, Pulau Bunaken, Sulawesi
source.author: travelourplanet.com

meanings.definition: A person whose work is collecting news and information, and sharing it with people through newspapers or other media.
examples: He is a journalist for the local television station.

images.alt: A person using a video camera.
images.description: A person holding a large video camera. The camera rests on the person's shoulder, and the person looks through a viewfinder as he records video.
images.caption: This journalist collects news with a camera.

meanings.definition: a unit of length equal to six feet, used to measure the depth of water or mines.
examples: The water was 5 fathoms, or 30 feet deep in the middle of the lake.

meanings.definition: A literary or dramatic work that makes fun of human vice or foolishness, usually through the use of parody or irony.
examples: The play is a satire that makes fun of upper-class snobbery.

images.alt: Magazine cover image of a man with a monacle.
images.description: A man wearing a tall top hat, high collared shirt, and fancy coat. He holds a monacle. He has his head tilted back, eyes slightly closed, and looks at a butterfly through the monacle.
images.caption: This image is a satire of the rich in the 1920s.

meanings.definition: To make fun of or laugh at in an unkind way.
examples: In the children's story, Rabbit's long ears left him open to ridicule from the other animals.

images.alt: A person looking sad while others look on.
images.description: A person leaning against a wall, looking worried and sad. In the near distance, two other people are looking at her, smiling.
images.caption: Ridicule can be a form of bullying.

source.title: Diverse classmates bullying Hispanic student in university
source.author: Keira Burton

meanings.definition: A sound, group of sounds, or the symbols for such sounds in writing that have some meaning.
examples: Twain used accents and slang words to bring his characters to life.

images.alt: Photo of letters on small square tiles.
images.description: Square wood tiles with letters spelling the word DREAM.
images.caption: The word DREAM.

meanings.definition: Legal permission to do something, or a paper or card that shows permission.
examples: He was licensed as a steamboat pilot.

images.description: A driver's license with UK printed in the upper left corner.
images.caption: A person who is licensed is able to legally drive a car.

meanings.definition: The place to which a person is going or goods or baggage are sent.
examples: In addition to writing articles and books, Mark Twain delighted audiences with his public lectures about the far-flung locations he visited on his travels.

images.alt: Photo of a map on a computer tablet.
images.description: A map displaying on a computer tablet. Roads and locations on the map are labeled.
images.caption: Roads and other locations are labeled on this map.

meanings.definition: Very unusual and interesting.
examples: People were eager to learn about his trips to then-exotic places, such as the Sandwich Islands (now Hawaii), Egypt and the Holy Land.

meanings.definition: The people and organizations that are in control of society or government.
examples: In 1889, Twain took on another establishment -- British royalty.

images.alt: Statue of a queen in front of a large, marble building.
images.description: A marble statue of Queen Victoria, wearing a crown and holding a golden orb in one hand and a scepter in the other, looking to the side. The golden orb and scepter are symbols of authority.
images.caption: A statue of Queen Victoria, a famous ruler of Britain.

meanings.definition: The language that is spoken or written in the common, everyday life of a people or region.
examples: Twain used accents and slang vernacular to bring his characters to life.

images.alt: Photo of letters on small square tiles.
images.description: Square wood tiles with letters spelling the word DREAM.
images.caption: A common word spelled out with letter tiles.

meanings.definition: Permission for an action; approval.
examples: He got legal sanction to be a steamboat pilot.

images.description: A driver's license with UK printed in the upper left corner.
images.caption: A person who has a license is legally sanctioned to drive a car.

meanings.definition: The place to which a person is going or goods or baggage are sent.
examples: In addition to writing articles and books, Mark Twain delighted audiences with his public lectures about the far-flung destinations he visited on his travels.

images.alt: Photo of a map on a computer tablet.
images.description: A map displaying on a computer tablet. Roads and locations on the map are labeled.
images.caption: Roads and other destinations are labeled on this map.

meanings.definition: Not known or experienced before; unusual; strange.
examples: People were eager to learn about his trips to then-unfamiliar places, such as the Sandwich Islands (now Hawaii), Egypt and the Holy Land.

meanings.definition: Permission for an action.
examples: He got legal approval to be a steamboat pilot.

images.description: A driver's license with UK printed in the upper left corner.
images.caption: A person who has a license is legally approved to drive a car.

meanings.definition: A location.
examples: In addition to writing articles and books, Mark Twain delighted audiences with his public lectures about the far-flung places he visited on his travels.

images.alt: Photo of a map on a computer tablet.
images.description: A map displaying on a computer tablet. Roads and locations on the map are labeled.
images.caption: Roads and other places are labeled on this map.

meanings.definition: Not the same; not alike.
examples: People were eager to learn about his trips to then-unfamiliar places, such as the Sandwich Islands (now Hawaii), Egypt and the Holy Land.

meanings.definition: An organization set up for a specific purpose, usually serving the public.
examples: In 1889, Twain took on another institution-- British royalty.

images.alt: Statue of a queen in front of a large, marble building.
images.description: A marble statue of Queen Victoria, wearing a crown and holding a golden orb in one hand and a scepter in the other, looking to the side. The golden orb and scepter are symbols of authority.
images.caption: A statue of Queen Victoria, a famous ruler of Britain.
